A.definition: The final order, pronouncement, or judgment of a court or tribunal.
An employee or agent of an insurance company who handles a casualty claim.
A statement or confession by a party to a lawsuit admitting certain facts.
A lawyer who represents a party in court or gives legal advice.
A jury verdict or judge's decision that a defendant is not guilty.
(“Friend of the court”)—a person or organization not party to a case but offering information or expertise to assist the court.
A historical common-law action for enforcing certain promises or obligations.
A person formally charged with a crime.
A declaration made before an authorized official that a document is genuine.
A principle or statement accepted as true without proof—used broadly in reasoning, including in legal logic.
A person (like a guardian) appointed by the court to represent another in a legal proceeding.
A Latin phrase meaning 'by stronger reason'—arguing that if one fact holds, another even stronger one logically follows.
The relinquishment or waiver of a right or interest, often in property law.
The unlawful taking away of a person by force or deception.
To reduce, remove, or eliminate, e.g., to abate a nuisance.
To renounce or reject solemnly, often under oath.

Voluntary refusal to accept an inheritance or legacy.
A summary record of a lien filed against property.
Filing lawsuits with malicious intent or without merit to harass.
Legal responsibility of a person who assists or encourages a crime.
A person obligated to pay under an account or contract.
Gradual accumulation of land by natural causes like sediment deposits.
Acceptance of a claim or fact by silence or inaction.
An act that demonstrates a person’s inability to pay debts.

A.term: Actus non facit reum nisi mens sit rea
A.definition: Latin: An act does not make a person guilty unless there is guilty intent.
Physical possession or use of property.
A court order authorizing collection and preservation of assets.
The part of a complaint stating the amount of damages claimed.
A standardized contract offered on a take-it-or-leave-it basis.
Postponement of a court session without setting a date to resume.
A person appointed to administer the remaining estate after an executor resigns or dies.
Permission given by a biological parent or guardian for adoption.
Based on the assessed value, especially for taxation.
A formal declaration by a claimant opposing another’s title or rights.
A witness whose testimony is unfavorable to the party calling them.
A court order requiring a party to take a specific action.
The attorney officially recognized as representing a party in a case.
A written statement of facts agreed upon by both parties to streamline a trial.
A provision in a mortgage requiring full repayment if the property is sold.
The person to whom property or rights are transferred.
The person who transfers property or rights to another.
Temporary spousal support during divorce proceedings.
A piece of paper attached to a negotiable instrument for endorsements.
Legal theory holding a corporation’s owners personally liable under certain conditions.
A court order commanding a party to perform an act or show cause why they should not.
A lack of clarity or uncertainty in language or terms.
A formal change or addition to a legal complaint.
A legal document submitted by a non-party offering information relevant to the case.
Additional remedies awarded in family law cases, like custody or maintenance.
A legal declaration that a marriage is null and void.
Written responses to formal questions in discovery.
A legal exemption from antitrust laws for specific activities or entities.
A court’s decision that can be challenged in a higher court.
Security posted to ensure payment of costs if an appeal is unsuccessful.
The authority of a court to review decisions of lower courts.
A right or privilege attached to property, such as easements or water rights.
The suitability of a dispute to be resolved by arbitration.
The act of detaining a person by legal authority.
Detaining a person without prior court approval under certain conditions.
Someone who intentionally sets fire to property.
A legal document establishing a corporation.
Assault is the threat or attempt; battery is the actual physical contact.
Agreement or approval, often to a contract or proposal.

A.term: Assignment for the benefit of creditors
A.definition: A transfer of assets to a third party to pay debts outside bankruptcy.
Taking responsibility for an existing mortgage loan.
Voluntarily accepting a known risk, limiting liability.
A court order allowing a creditor to seize property to satisfy a debt.
The attorney officially recognized as representing a party in legal proceedings.
The charges billed by a lawyer for legal services.
A tenant’s acknowledgment of a new landlord.
A report confirming the accuracy of financial statements.
The principle that no person should be judged without a fair hearing.
The legal power to act or make decisions.
A suspension of creditor actions upon the filing of bankruptcy.
A system of weights used in commerce.
From the beginning; void from the outset.
Improper use of legal procedures for ulterior purposes.
An agreement to an offer, creating a contract.
The right to consult with a lawyer.
A person who assists in a crime without directly committing it.
Agreement resolving a dispute and fulfilling an obligation.
A mutual agreement of the amount owed.
The accumulation of something, such as interest or rights.
A legal judgment of not guilty.
An unforeseen natural event like a flood or earthquake.
The physical act of committing a crime.
A judge’s increase in damages awarded by a jury.
Evidence allowed to be presented in court.
The legal process of taking another’s child as one’s own.
A sworn written statement made under oath.
A solemn declaration equivalent to an oath.
A relationship where one party acts on behalf of another.
The transfer of property or rights.
A citizen of a country hostile to the state where they reside.
Distribution of financial loss among responsible parties.
A change or modification in a legal document.
The legal addition of territory to a city or state.
A yearly meeting of shareholders or members of an organization.
Laws designed to prevent monopolies and promote competition.
A request to a higher court to review a lower court’s decision.
Unauthorized use of another’s name or property, or allocation of funds.
A process where a neutral third party resolves disputes outside of court.
Legal seizure of property to satisfy a judgment or claim.
The removal or cessation of a nuisance.
A summary of the legal history of a property’s ownership.
Complete immunity from liability for statements made in certain contexts.
The gradual addition of land by natural forces like water or sediment.
Agreement or acceptance through silence or lack of objection.
Legislation passed by a parliament.
A lawsuit directed against property rather than a person.
The ability of a party to understand and participate in legal proceedings.
A person appointed to manage the estate of someone who dies without a will.
The final court order legally establishing an adoption.
An incident causing harm or injury, often used in medical law.
A sworn statement confirming that documents were properly delivered.
A defense admitting the facts but presenting other facts to avoid liability.
The obligations an agent owes to their principal, such as loyalty and care.
A contract where one party agrees to sell and another to buy property.
Evidence showing a defendant was elsewhere when a crime occurred.
Financial support paid to a spouse after separation or divorce.
Holding a corporation’s owners personally liable when corporate formalities are ignored.
A formal change to a legal document or legislation.
Additional court orders related to a divorce, such as child custody or maintenance.
A phrase used to indicate that either one or both options may apply.
A defendant’s formal written response to a complaint.
Another term for prenuptial agreement, outlining property rights before marriage.
When one party indicates they will not perform their contractual duties before the performance date.
A security deposit posted by an appellant to ensure payment of costs if the appeal fails.
A court that reviews decisions of lower courts.
Something belonging to or attached to something else, especially land.
Subject to arbitration.
A neutral third party who resolves disputes outside of court.
The court proceeding where charges are formally read and a plea is entered.
The act of detaining a person by legal authority.
The transfer of rights or property to another party.
A defense asserting that the plaintiff knowingly accepted the risk involved.
A court-ordered seizure of property to secure a judgment.
The fees charged by a lawyer for their services.
Someone authorized to act on another’s behalf, usually through a power of attorney.
Latin phrase meaning 'hear the other side,' a principle of natural justice.
The legal power to act or make decisions.
A temporary halt to all collection activities against a debtor after bankruptcy filing.
The transfer of rights or interests in property or contracts.
The sudden removal of land by natural forces.
A reduction or cancellation of a debt due to specific circumstances.
A document summarizing a court’s judgment to create a lien on property.
Liability without fault or negligence.
When a party formally acknowledges receipt of legal documents.
The right to obtain evidence necessary for a legal case.
A contract in which parties agree to settle a dispute and fulfill obligations.
An agreement between parties on the amount owed.
The time when a legal claim arises.
A legal judgment that the defendant is not guilty.
An act demonstrating a debtor’s inability to pay debts.
The physical act of committing a crime.
A judge’s increase of damages awarded by a jury.
The ability of a party to understand and participate in legal proceedings.
A person appointed to manage the remainder of an estate after the original administrator dies or resigns.
Permission given by a parent or guardian for a child’s adoption.
A tax based on the assessed value of property or goods.
An unexpected harmful occurrence, often used in medical law.
A sworn statement supporting the validity of a claim, often in malpractice cases.
When a principal’s actions cause a third party to believe an agent has authority.

B.definition: okulaya olukwe
The temporary release of an accused person awaiting trial, sometimes on condition that a sum of money guarantees their appearance in court.
A legal process through which individuals or businesses unable to repay debts may seek relief from some or all of their obligations.
A violation or failure to perform any term of a contract, written or oral, without a legitimate legal excuse.
The obligation to prove one's assertion or charge, typically resting on the party bringing a claim.
A trial by judge, as opposed to a trial by jury.
A person who receives benefits or assets under a will, trust, insurance policy, or other legal document.
A gift of personal property made through a will.
A financial security that represents a loan made by an investor to a borrower, typically used as collateral in legal matters.
The unlawful entry into a building with intent to commit a crime, especially theft.
A written document presented to a court arguing why one party should prevail.
In good faith; genuine or real.
A formal statement of the fundamental rights of the people of a nation.
All evidence collected and presented in support of a legal case.
The obligation to present evidence to the court.
A secured warehouse where goods are stored until customs duties are paid.
The true owner of property or assets, even if the title is in another name.
A method of voting, typically secret, used in elections.
A violation or infraction of a law, obligation, or agreement.
The legal profession as a whole; also refers to the examination for admission to practice law.
The crime of demanding money or another benefit from someone in return for not revealing compromising or damaging information.

C.definition: Law developed through decisions of courts and similar tribunals.
A legally enforceable agreement between two or more parties.
The initial pleading by which a lawsuit is begun.
A formal declaration that someone is guilty of a criminal offense.
The questioning of a witness by the opposing party in a trial.
The protective care or guardianship of someone or something, often relating to children or detainees.
An act of disobedience or disrespect toward a court or its procedures.
A body of rules that defines private rights and remedies and governs disputes between individuals.
A system of law concerned with the punishment of those who commit crimes.
A legal right that grants the creator of original work exclusive rights to its use and distribution.
A legal reason for bringing a lawsuit.
The legally authorized killing of someone as punishment for a crime.
A lawyer or group of lawyers giving legal advice and conducting cases in court.
A person or institution to whom money is owed.
A person who makes a formal charge or files a lawsuit.
Evidence that confirms or supports a statement, theory, or finding.
Law derived from judicial decisions instead of from statutes.
A fee paid to a lawyer only if the case is won.
A warning or caution, often placed on public records to prevent certain actions.
Movable personal property that is not real estate.
